elements.content: A new cyanide-bearing molecular precursor, mer-[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- (1), and a zigzag chain, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3][Mn(salen)]·4H2O (2), were prepared and characterized in terms of structure and magnetism. Magnetic data reveal that intrachain antiferromagnetic couplings via cyanide ligands in 2 are clearly operating, resulting in a ferrimagnetic nature.
elements.clean_text: A new cyanide-bearing molecular precursor, mer-[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- (1), and a zigzag chain, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3][Mn(salen)]⋅4H2O (2), were prepared and characterized in terms of structure and magnetism. Magnetic data reveal that intrachain antiferromagnetic couplings via cyanide ligands in 2 are clearly operating, resulting in a ferrimagnetic nature.

elements.content: A new cyanide-bearing molecular precursor, mer-[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- (1), and a zigzag chain, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3][Mn(salen)]·4H2O (2), were characterized structurally and magnetically. The magnetic properties of 2 indicate the presence of intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions via cyanide bridges, eventually exhibiting a ferrimagnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text: A new cyanide-bearing molecular precursor, mer-[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- (1), and a zigzag chain, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3][Mn(salen)]⋅4H2O (2), were characterized structurally and magnetically. The magnetic properties of 2 indicate the presence of intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions via cyanide bridges, eventually exhibiting a ferrimagnetic behavior.

elements.content: Extensive works on low-dimensional magnetic materials have been carried out because of the fundamental interest (quantum tunneling of magnetization, for example) and their potential applications in magnetic information storage materials. To attain these systems, the employment of capped molecular entities [ML p (CN) q ] n - (M = paramagnetic metal ions; L = polydentate ligand) is appropriate because the precursors with chelating ligands can control the structural evolution in constrained directions and, as a result, generate low-dimensional magnetic assemblies. Among them, the FeIII complexes have attracted special attention because they serve as magnetic anisotropic sources. Some of the pertinent building blocks used to date are [Fe(A)(CN)4]- [A = bidentate nitrogen donor; 2,2‘-bipyridine (bpy); 1,10-phenanthroline (phen); 2,2‘-bipyrimidine (bpym)], fac-[Fe(B)(CN)3]- (B = facially coordinate tridentate ligand; hydrotris(pyrazolyl)borate (Tp); hydrotris(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)borate (Tp*); tetra(pyrazol-1-yl)borate (pzTp); tach = 1,3,5-triaminocyclohexane (tach)], mer-[Fe(C)(CN)3]- [C = meridionally coordinate tridentate ligand; bis(2-pyridylcarbonyl)amidate anion (bpca); 8-(pyridine-2-carboxamido)quinoline anion (pcq)], and [Fe(D)(CN)2]- [D = tetradentate ligand; 1,2-bis(pyridine-2-carboxamido)benzenate (bpb)]. On the other hand, MnIII Schiff bases with enhanced Jahn−Teller effects are also other anisotropic origins to fabricate such complexes. Thus, the combination of both anisotropic molecular precursors would be one of the rational strategies to achieve intriguing low-dimensional entities.
elements.clean_text: Extensive works on low-dimensional magnetic materials have been carried out because of the fundamental interest (quantum tunneling of magnetization, for example) and their potential applications in magnetic information storage materials. To attain these systems, the employment of capped molecular entities [ML p (CN) q ] n  - (M = paramagnetic metal ions; L = polydentate ligand) is appropriate because the precursors with chelating ligands can control the structural evolution in constrained directions and, as a result, generate low-dimensional magnetic assemblies. Among them, the FeIII complexes have attracted special attention because they serve as magnetic anisotropic sources. Some of the pertinent building blocks used to date are [Fe(A)(CN)4]- [A = bidentate nitrogen donor; 2,2‘-bipyridine (bpy); 1,10-phenanthroline (phen); 2,2‘-bipyrimidine (bpym)], fac-[Fe(B)(CN)3]- (B = facially coordinate tridentate ligand; hydrotris(pyrazolyl)borate (Tp); hydrotris(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)borate (Tp*); tetra(pyrazol-1-yl)borate (pzTp); tach = 1,3,5-triaminocyclohexane (tach)], mer-[Fe(C)(CN)3]- [C = meridionally coordinate tridentate ligand; bis(2-pyridylcarbonyl)amidate anion (bpca); 8-(pyridine-2-carboxamido)quinoline anion (pcq)], and [Fe(D)(CN)2]- [D = tetradentate ligand; 1,2-bis(pyridine-2-carboxamido)benzenate (bpb)]. On the other hand, MnIII Schiff bases with enhanced Jahn-Teller effects are also other anisotropic origins to fabricate such complexes. Thus, the combination of both anisotropic molecular precursors would be one of the rational strategies to achieve intriguing low-dimensional entities.

elements.content: Herein we report the synthesis, structures, and magnetic properties of a new molecular building unit, (PPh4)[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3] [1; pzcq = 8-(pyrazine-2-carboxamido)quinoline anion], and a one-dimensional bimetallic chain, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3][Mn(salen)]·4H2O [2; salen = N‘,N‘-ethylenebis(salicylideneiminato) dianion]. It is worth noting that 2 is the first example of the cyanide-bridged FeIII−MnIII ferrimagnetic chain constructed by the low-spin FeIII precursor bearing three CN ligands with a mer arrangement and the MnIII Schiff base.
elements.clean_text: Herein we report the synthesis, structures, and magnetic properties of a new molecular building unit, (PPh4)[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3] [1; pzcq = 8-(pyrazine-2-carboxamido)quinoline anion], and a one-dimensional bimetallic chain, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3][Mn(salen)]⋅4H2O [2; salen = N‘,N‘-ethylenebis(salicylideneiminato) dianion]. It is worth noting that 2 is the first example of the cyanide-bridged FeIII-MnIII ferrimagnetic chain constructed by the low-spin FeIII precursor bearing three CN ligands with a mer arrangement and the MnIII Schiff base.

elements.content: A stoichiometric reaction of [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- and [Mn(salen)(H2O)](ClO4) in MeOH gave brown crystals of 2 in good yield. No Cl−O stretching vibrations in the IR spectrum indicate that the reaction is completed. The characteristic CN peaks of the molecular precursors are observed at 2114m cm-1 (1) and 2123m cm-1 for K[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]. Compound 2 has CN peaks evident at 2143w and 2123m cm-1. In 2, the first band is assignable to bridging CN groups, which is due to the peak shift toward higher frequencies compared with the precursor, and the second is due to the remaining free CN ligands.
elements.clean_text: A stoichiometric reaction of [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- and [Mn(salen)(H2O)](ClO4) in MeOH gave brown crystals of 2 in good yield. No Cl-O stretching vibrations in the IR  spectrum indicate that the reaction is completed. The characteristic CN peaks of the molecular precursors are observed at 2114m cm-1 (1) and 2123m cm-1 for K[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]. Compound 2 has CN peaks evident at 2143w and 2123m cm-1. In 2, the first band is assignable to bridging CN groups, which is due to the peak shift toward higher frequencies compared with the precursor, and the second is due to the remaining free CN ligands.

elements.content: Both complexes crystallize in the monoclinic system as analyzed by X-ray crystallography (Figures S1 in the Supporting Information and 1). Each Fe center of the compounds adopts a distorted octahedral environment consisting of three N atoms from a planar pzcq and three C atoms from three CN groups. The bond lengths of Fe−C(cyanide) are in the ranges of 1.964−1.970 Å for 1 and 1.938−1.959 Å for 2, which demonstrate that the coordination of the blocked building unit to the metal ions gives rise to the enhanced C−N bond order as checked by the IR spectra. The obtained bond distances are consistent with those of the related [Fe(bpca)(CN)3]- and [Fe(pcq)(CN)3]- compounds. The Fe−N(amide) distance (1.88−1.89 Å) is significantly shorter than the other two Fe−N lengths (1.94−1.96 Å) associated with pzcq, which is due to the presence of a strong σ-donor effect of the deprotonated amide. The Fe−CN bond angles are almost linear (172.4−178.1°). The [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- moiety can behave as a bridging group between [Mn(salen)]+ entities in the cis mode, and the resultant self-assembly process leads to a neutral one-dimensional chain with a zigzag structural pattern. In the [Mn(salen)]+ unit, the Mn atom can be viewed as a distorted octahedral geometry based on equatorial N2O2 donor atoms from salen [Mn1−O2 = 1.885(3) Å, Mn1−O3 = 1.878(3) Å, Mn1−N9 = 1.985(3) Å, and Mn1−N10 = 1.983(3) Å] and two apical N atoms from bridging CN groups [Mn1−N1 = 2.288(3) Å and Mn1a−N3 = 2.263(3) Å; a, −x + 0.5, y − 0.5, −z + 0.5]. The axial elongation accounts for the existence of the well-known Jahn−Teller effect on an octahedral high-spin MnIII ion. The bridging CN groups form two Mn−NC angles of 152.2(3)° for Mn1−N1−C1 and 158.3(3)° for Mn1a−N3−C3 within a chain. These results are compared with the cyanide-linked FeIII−MnIII chain containing the facial [Fe(Tp)(CN)3]- anion in which two Mn−NC angles are more different by 10°. The torsion angles are −2(4)° for Fe1−C1−N1−Mn1 and 75(3)° for Fe1−C3−N3−Mn1a. The distances between Fe and Mn ions on the same chain, separated through the CN links, are similar, 5.179(1) Å for Fe1−Mn1 and 5.240(1) Å for Fe1−Mn1a. The angle between the elongated axes of the neighboring MnIII ions within the chain is 110.6°. The shortest interchain Fe−Fe separation between nearby chains is 7.194 Å. The π−π contacts between the two C atoms (C4 and C5) on the pyridyl groups of pzcq ligands in disparate adjacent chains, which run parallel with the chains in most proximity, are not substantial. This is because the Fe−Fe distance of 8.001 Å via the π−π interactions is even larger than the shortest interchain Fe−Fe spacing (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information).

Each Fe center of the compounds adopts a distorted octahedral environment consisting of three N atoms from a planar pzcq and three C atoms from three CN groups. The bond lengths of Fe-C(cyanide) are in the ranges of 1.964-1.970 Å for 1 and 1.938-1.959 Å for 2, which demonstrate that the coordination of the blocked building unit to the metal ions gives rise to the enhanced C-N bond order as checked by the IR spectra. The obtained bond distances are consistent with those of the related [Fe(bpca)(CN)3]- and [Fe(pcq)(CN)3]- compounds. The Fe-N(amide) distance (1.88-1.89 Å) is significantly shorter than the other two Fe-N lengths (1.94-1.96 Å) associated with pzcq, which is due to the presence of a strong σ-donor effect of the deprotonated amide. The Fe-CN bond angles are almost linear (172.4-178.1°). The [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- moiety can behave as a bridging group between [Mn(salen)]+ entities in the cis mode, and the resultant self-assembly process leads to a neutral one-dimensional chain with a zigzag structural pattern. In the [Mn(salen)]+ unit, the Mn atom can be viewed as a distorted octahedral geometry based on equatorial N2O2 donor atoms from salen [Mn1-O2 = 1.885(3) Å, Mn1-O3 = 1.878(3) Å, Mn1-N9 = 1.985(3) Å, and Mn1-N10 = 1.983(3) Å] and two apical N atoms from bridging CN groups [Mn1-N1 = 2.288(3) Å and Mn1a-N3 = 2.263(3) Å; a, -x + 0.5, y - 0.5, -z + 0.5]. The axial elongation accounts for the existence of the well-known Jahn-Teller effect on an octahedral high-spin MnIII ion. The bridging CN groups form two Mn-NC angles of 152.2(3)° for Mn1-N1-C1 and 158.3(3)° for Mn1a-N3-C3 within a chain. These results are compared with the cyanide-linked FeIII-MnIII chain containing the facial [Fe(Tp)(CN)3]- anion in which two Mn-NC angles are more different by 10°. The torsion angles are -2(4)° for Fe1-C1-N1-Mn1 and 75(3)° for Fe1-C3-N3-Mn1a. The distances between Fe and Mn ions on the same chain, separated through the CN links, are similar, 5.179(1) Å for Fe1-Mn1 and 5.240(1) Å for Fe1-Mn1a. The angle between the elongated axes of the neighboring MnIII ions within the chain is 110.6°. The shortest interchain Fe-Fe separation between nearby chains is 7.194 Å. This is because the Fe-Fe distance of 8.001 Å via the π-π interactions is even larger than the shortest interchain Fe-Fe spacing (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Molecular view of2 showing (a) the atom-labeling scheme and (b) bimetallic chain structure. Symmetry code:  a, −x + 0.5, y − 0.5, −z + 0.5.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular view of2 showing (a) the atom-labeling scheme and (b) bimetallic chain structure. Symmetry code: a, -x + 0.5, y - 0.5, -z + 0.5.

elements.content: The effective magnetic moment of 1 at 1000 G is 2.12 μB, which is larger than the spin-only value (1.73 μB) for a low-spin FeIII (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). As the temperature decreases, the moment gradually declines, indicating characteristic unquenched orbital angular momentum of octahedral low-spin FeIII systems.
elements.clean_text: The effective magnetic moment of 1 at 1000 G is 2.12 μB, which is larger than the spin-only value (1.73 μB) for a low-spin FeIII (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). As the temperature decreases, the moment gradually declines, indicating characteristic unquenched orbital angular momentum of octahedral low-spin FeIII systems.

elements.content: As illustrated in Figure , thermal variation of the magnetic susceptibility for 2 was collected in the temperature range of 2−300 K at 1 kG. The χm T value of 3.347 cm3 K mol-1 is somewhat smaller than the theoretical one (3.375 cm3 K mol-1) calculated from one isolated FeIII (S Fe = 1/2) spin and one MnIII (S Mn = 2) spin with g = 2. Lowering the temperature causes χm T to be diminished down to 2.032 cm3 K mol-1 at 9 K, clearly suggesting the existence of intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions between Fe and Mn centers transmitted by CN bridges. It is worth noting that the magnetic behavior at T > 9 K is in contrast to ferromagnetic interactions observed in the FeIII−MnIII chain formed by a fac-[Fe(Tp)(CN)3]- anion and most of the other related FeIII−MnIII systems. It appears that the FeIII−C⋮N−MnIII unit can provide either antiferromagnetic or ferromagnetic alignments depending on the subtle structural variations present in bridging pathways. An abrupt rise in χm T below the minimum temperature is obviously relevant with the pronounced correlation of noncompensated spins along the chain, which is normally observed in ferrimagnetic systems. The Curie−Weiss law can be applicable to the linear part of the inverse magnetic susceptibility data (40−300 K). It affords C = 3.794 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = −28.9 K, signifying the existence of antiferromagnetic couplings between neighboring magnetic centers (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). To get further insight into the underlying magnetic nature in 2, the field dependence of the magnetization at 0−7 T and 2 K was investigated (inset of Figure ). The magnetization data per FeMn display a constant increase as the field is raised, reaching a value of 2.51 Nβ at 7 T, which is slightly smaller than the theoretical value of 3 Nβ obtained from the ferrimagnetic consequence (gS Mn − gS Fe), assuming g = 2. The reduced magnetization versus H/T plots show that the isofield curves are not superimposed (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information).

The χm T value of 3.347 cm3 K mol-1 is somewhat smaller than the theoretical one (3.375 cm3 K mol-1) calculated from one isolated FeIII (S Fe = 1/2) spin and  one MnIII (S Mn = 2) spin with g = 2. Lowering the temperature causes χm T to be diminished down to 2.032 cm3 K mol-1 at 9 K, clearly suggesting the existence of intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions between Fe and Mn centers transmitted by CN bridges. It is worth noting that the magnetic behavior at T > 9 K is in contrast to ferromagnetic interactions observed in the FeIII-MnIII chain formed by a fac-[Fe(Tp)(CN)3]- anion and most of the other related FeIII-MnIII systems. It appears that the FeIII-C⋮N-MnIII unit can provide either antiferromagnetic or ferromagnetic alignments depending on the subtle structural variations present in bridging pathways. An abrupt rise in χm T below the minimum temperature is obviously relevant with the pronounced correlation of noncompensated spins along the chain, which is normally observed in ferrimagnetic systems. The Curie-Weiss law can be applicable to the linear part of the inverse magnetic susceptibility data (40-300 K). It affords C = 3.794 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -28.9 K, signifying the existence of antiferromagnetic couplings between neighboring magnetic centers (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). To get further insight into the underlying magnetic nature in 2, the field dependence of the magnetization at 0-7 T and 2 K was investigated (inset of Figure ). The magnetization data per FeMn display a constant increase as the field is raised, reaching a value of 2.51 Nβ at 7 T, which is slightly smaller than the theoretical value of 3 Nβ obtained from the ferrimagnetic consequence (gS Mn - gS Fe), assuming g = 2. The reduced magnetization versus H/T plots show that the isofield curves are not superimposed (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Plot of χm T versus T of 2. The inset shows the field dependence of the magnetization at 2 K.
elements.clean_text: 2  Plot of χm T versus T of 2. The inset shows the field dependence of the magnetization at 2 K.

elements.content: To examine the spin dynamics for 2, alternating current (ac) susceptibility was recorded at zero dc field and an ac field of 5 G with oscillating frequencies. As depicted in Figure , the frequency-dependent out-of-phase term (χm‘ ‘) in the ac data was discernible below 2.7 K. Increasing the frequency from 1000 to 9000 Hz renders the magnitude of χm‘ ‘ to grow gradually with no maxima visible even at 1.8 K. The advent of the nonzero χm‘ ‘ component is concerned with spin glasses, long-range ferromagnetic orderings, and single-chain magnets. The fact that 2 is crystalline without structural disorder precludes the possibility of a spin glass. The shift of the peak temperature (=T max) in χm‘T and the estimated quantity may favor single-chain magnet characters rather than long-range ferromagnetic order, but it remains elusive at this stage.
elements.clean_text: To examine the spin dynamics for 2, alternating current (ac) susceptibility was recorded at zero dc field and an ac field of 5 G with oscillating frequencies. As depicted in Figure , the frequency-dependent out-of-phase term (χm‘‘) in the ac data was discernible below 2.7 K. Increasing the frequency from 1000 to 9000 Hz renders the magnitude of χm‘‘ to grow gradually with no maxima visible even at 1.8 K. The advent of the nonzero χm‘‘ component is concerned with spin glasses, long-range ferromagnetic orderings, and single-chain magnets. The fact that 2 is crystalline without structural disorder precludes the possibility of a spin glass. The shift of the peak temperature (=T max) in χm‘T and the estimated quantity may favor single-chain magnet characters rather than long-range ferromagnetic order, but it remains elusive at this stage.

elements.content: Plot of χm‘ ‘ versus T of 2 at an ac field of 5 G, zero dc field, and several indicated frequencies. The inset represents the temperature dependence of χm‘T.
elements.clean_text: 3  Plot of χm‘‘ versus T of 2 at an ac field of 5 G, zero dc field, and several indicated frequencies. The inset represents the temperature dependence of χm‘T.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully prepared a new molecular building block, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- (1), and a one-dimensional bimetallic compound, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3][Mn(salen)]·4H2O (2), with a zigzag chain structure. Noticeably, intrachain antiferromagnetic couplings through the FeIII−CN−MnIII pathways are operative in 2. The molecular precursor, mer-[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]-, may be one of the good building units to produce single-chain magnets when noncovalent contacts between chains are completely suppressed.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully prepared a new molecular building block, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]- (1), and a one-dimensional bimetallic compound, [Fe(pzcq)(CN)3][Mn(salen)]⋅4H2O (2), with a zigzag chain structure. Noticeably, intrachain antiferromagnetic couplings through the FeIII-CN-MnIII pathways are operative in 2. The molecular precursor, mer-[Fe(pzcq)(CN)3]-, may be one of the good building units to produce single-chain magnets when noncovalent contacts between chains are completely suppressed.

elements.content:
X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format and additional synthetic, structural, and magnetic data for 1 and 2. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Ferrimagnetic FeIII−MnIII Zigzag Chain Formed by a New mer-Positioned
Iron(III) Cyanide Precursor
